user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of unescape_wrapper:
```c
static size_t
unescape_wrapper (void *cls,
                  struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                  char *val)
{
  bool broken;
  size_t res;
  (void) cls; /* Mute compiler warning. */

  /* TODO: add individual parameter */
  if (0 <= connection->daemon->client_discipline)
    return MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_strict_ (val);

  res = MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_lenient_ (val, &broken);
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  if (broken)
  {
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("The URL encoding is broken.\n"));
  }
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
  return res;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("The URL encoding is broken.\n"));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment calls MHD_DLOG(...) and the translation macro _(...). Neither call is the function unescape_wrapper itself, so there is no direct self-call. This does not violate Rule 17.2. (Only if the implementation of MHD_DLOG or _ were to call back into unescape_wrapper — e.g. via a logging callback that invokes the same URL-decoding path — would an indirect recursion arise; nothing in the shown code indicates that.)
